Der Zahlenname Billion bedeutet im internationalen Sprachgebrauch die Zahl 1000 Milliarden oder 1.000.000.000.000 = 1012, also im Dezimalsystem für eine Eins gefolgt von 12 Nullen. 1000 Billionen sind eine Milliarde.
Laut den Franzosen im 19. Jahrhundert haben die Amerikaner fälschlicherweise zusammengefasst, dass eine Billion eine Milliarde ist, was die Franzosen korrigierten, aber die Amerikaner wollten sich nicht anpassen und blieben bei einer Billion ... der Fehler wurde weitergegeben und 1978 Unter amerikanischem Druck hat das britische Parlament entschieden, dass die Briten dem amerikanischen (falschen) Modell folgen werden. Es war also eine politische Entscheidung und keine sprachliche ... Wenn wir also Englisch als „Universalsprache“ verwenden, müssen wir auch im Englischen den internationalen Sprachgebrauch verwenden: Eine Billion ist also 1000 Milliarden. "Einheimische" sollten ihre Einheiten aus der halben Vergangenheit verwenden: Faranheids, Billionen, Unzen ...

The number name billion means in international usage the number 1000 milliards or 1,000,000,000,000 = 10(12), i.e. in the decimal system for a one followed by 12 zeros. 1000 billions is a one billiard and 1000 billiards is one trillion.
The history: according to the French in the 19th century, Americans mistakenly summarized that a billiard is an actuall milliard, which the French corrected later, but Americans would not conform and stuck with a wrong number billion... the error was passed on and in 1978 under American pressure the British Parliament decided that the British will follow the American mistaken model. So it was a political decision for the internal USA-UK comaptiblity and not a linguistic one...
So if we use English as the "universal language" on the universal media as is the internet, we must also use international usage in English: So a billion is 1000 milliards. "Natives" should use their exsotic units: faranheids, billions, ounces... but only for their local public, when you go "global" use the metric system, Celsius and the correct math as it is use among 96% of the world population. Don't trash the internet with the wrong math, there is allready too much confusion...

Update:

The beginning of the end of the empire may be coming. In Europe, one of their main bases, Pavement ants set up a resistance in Italy and are slowly pushing their way towards Spain, which is the Argentine ant's heart in Europe. If Spain falls to the Pavement ants Europe may fall as well. Also, in Japan, RIFA, (Invicta), has shown up on the shores of the empire. As well as this, more land concerned means having to adapt to the climate, and that means more genetic diversity. In Kobe in Japan, three factions are beginning to fight each other and the rest of Japan. Some individuals in Tokyo are also becoming hostile. The split in loyalty could leave them vulnerable to Invicta once again.
If Europe and Japan fall, that would be catastrophic. The empire's best bet would be Australia, which RIFA has also appeared on.
(Note: Studying ants is hard and confusing, so some facts may be off.)

1:20 - This scene breaks my roku tv. Because my tv is technically capable of 1080/60, it attempts the scene. Because most scenes in any general 1080/60 video don't have almost every pixel changing every millisecond, the compressed video streams easily. However, this scene -- about 10 seconds -- will not display on my roku tv because the compression is lousy when every pixel is changing every millisecond. At least, that's my theory. Of course if I skip this scene, I can watch the rest of the video. It might make an interesting video to talk about scenes that are so difficult to compress that you end up breaking the system tolerances, if only temporarily.

I experienced a flash red vs black flying ant war. Everything was normal then within about 5 mins or so of seeing the first one they were swarming everywhere in an area about 1 acre across and about 30 feet high. It got so bad that pairs of combatants were dropping out of the sky everywhere like a mild rain shower. It got so intense that we just decided to shut down and break early for lunch. When we came back about 45 mins later there was a covering of dead ants on our whole job site like a layer of black and red hail stones but no clue who won or what area they were even fighting over. It made us think that was probably how animal populations felt whenever they find themselves in a battle zone of ours..........they just leave and come back when the fighters are done killing each other and just hope you can pick back up where you left off. Not really a common thing to find yourself trapped in war between a different species as a human (for me anyway).........it was an unforgettable experience.

I once lived in California for two years, and I was shocked by the just sheer volume of ants in the houses. In the walls, throughout the plumbing, inside the bathroom, pouring out of sockets and outlets; there was just no end to them! You would kill and kill and kill and kill ants but there were always more. No matter what you sprayed, no matter how you cleaned, no matter any number of cracks you filled, they would ALWAYS find a way inside the house, and don't DARE leave some dishes in the sink! You could walk away from the dinner table for five minutes, and when you get back there's more black in your rice than white.
From what this video said, that put us right smack dab in the middle of their territory, which explains a lot. Even though it's years later, it's good to finally have answers for the night terrors I lived through.

We got an Argentine ant infestation at my house recently, and we all had to move to a hotel for a few days because the exterminators had to really go all out to get rid of them, and we still sometimes find dead bodies or lone ants just hanging around.
Make sure to thank any any veterans out there.

Ever since I was a kid, I always wanted to make a video game called The Rules ofNature: Insect Warfare. The game would have different game modes where every player plays as an insect in a shooter style game. This would be the main gamemode, with red ants having red leaf bases and outposts, and green ants having green leaf bases and outposts. It would play like Battlefield but the maps would be in trees. The ants would mainly melee but you could also spit acid.

Another game mode would be bees vs wasps. I would try to keep the game as realistic as possible, but obviously I'd have to take some liberties to make the game more fun and playable. And don't worry, there wouldn't be any spiders.

Imagine the attacking team has to take over outposts (slowly capturing them when there are no enemy ants in the area). Once all outposts are captured, they can attack the main base where one player can become the Queen who has special abilites and more health. Destroying larvae would reduce the enemy team's reinforcements (like Battlefront 2017) and you win by either killing the queen, destroying the enemy base, or wiping out every enemy ant. 100 vs 100.

When you first start the game, the very first thing you saw would be an option; PG Mode, or True Nature Mode.

PG Mode would make the game more PG.

True Nature Mode would allow blood, dismemberment, and brutal takedowns and death animations.

Question: Do you think you are a good person? If so, have you ever stolen anything, lied, looked lustfully, or used God’s name in vain? (Oh God, Jesus Christ, etc.) If you have done this, you have violated God’s moral law, you admit that you are a liar, a thief, a blasphemer, and an adulterer at heart. So, if God gave you justice right away, would you be innocent or guilty? Obviously guilty. Heaven or hell? Obviously hell because you are a criminal in God's eyes. Don’t ask for forgiveness, try it in court: Judge, I raped a woman and killed her, but I’m so sorry and I won’t do it again. You would still go to jail because you shouldn’t do it again and you should be sorry. So is there any hope? Yes, there is! Out of love and mercy, God became a human being, Jesus Christ. Jesus lived a sinless life and finally died on the cross to bear the punishment we deserve. His resurrection proved that His death( more accurately, His sacrifical Blood) was enough to pay our penalty, the penalty for our sins. When someone pays your fine, the judge can leave you, dismiss your case, it’s the same with God. Jesus paid our penalty and in order to accept the free gift of salvation from God, we must believe (have faith in Jesus for our salvation, His finished work on the Cross). That's it! God bless you and feel free to ask me any question about this.

So as long as the being may adapt to its new landscape, in many cases, their competitors will stsy behing and many will go extinct

That is way, generally spesking, exotic may be considered plagues, once they make the ecossystem so unbalanced they can lead native species to extinction. So this is the forgotten civil war in our history in America. The ultimate gang war between the Red Fire Ants and the “Blue” Argentina Ants combating over who rules the territory. Though, it looks like the Red Fire Ants claim America for now lol. As for the future battles coming up, you got:
WW3 - (Ants versus insects) Should be an easy victory since they’ve got the numbers.
WW4 - (Ants versus any type of predators) Won’t be an easy challenge. Many will lay down their lives in this war.
WW5 - (Ants versus their nemesis, i.e. anteaters) You gonna need more than strength in numbers to tackle them.
WWA - (Ants versus roaches and any other radioactive insects survivors) Hell on Earth.
NWO - (Ants versus Mother Nature) In case they made it this far, their main objective would be to survive Nature’s wrath as the storm brews. Hope they like swimming.

As for the secret war that’s still ongoing, the war between the ants and the humans are undetermined. In efforts to destroy a colony, three will pop up in its place. And so on...

i had a past with fire ants, ant entire colony tried attacking my left foot when i was 6, i didn't feel a thing until the bites were agitated by time. these days fire ants leave me alone, i try to be out of the way of their supply lines when i sit down to meditate, i have received a few bites because i was in the way without knowing it. fire ants when i would go hiking years ago would jump on me from the trees and they love to bite the webbed skin between my fingers or my elbow i usually flick them off when i find one that didn't bite me. when i was old enough i quite literally almost eradicated the local invasive population of fire ants by dropping poison on their nests and hitting it with a stick like a normally do to rile them up and to demonstrate my qualms with them. after that the just left me alone, perhaps they have me scent and have a list of Humans not to provoke. there was at one time a nest on the post of my mailbox at the height of their holdings on my land. the usually rumbling of the mail box opening used to rile them up. they don't respond to it. i still prod with a stick to see if they are alive and usually they are unless i hit too hard and they abandon the next. i only go with one or two hits with a stick

from my poison bombings i took out most of their holdings on my land except for a few centers i couldn't quite get the fix on with poisons. i still find the supply chains but i let them be, if i am next to one when i decide to lay down i will observe

When I was a child growing up in the '70s in So. California I always had a great facination with ant's. The three most common ants you would find around were Argentine, fire ants (the indigenous type, not the S. American which were more agressive and venomous), and the big red Harvester ants. Even as a little kid I could see the Argentine ants slowly taking over and I hated it because I found them so uninteresting and whenever I saw them doing battle with other ants, I would always help the other ants, lol. Regardless of my help, in a mater of a few years all you saw were Argentine ants and it's basically been like that up until about 5 or 6 years ago. Now the indigenous fire ants are making a big comeback and I actually see more of them than Argentine ants where I live. It used to be whenever there were ants in the house, they were always Argentine ants, but for the first time, now any ants we get in the house are what I call micro ants. They are these very tiny black ants I've never seen before, much smaller than an Argentine ant and have a stubby shape, but also have multiple queens.

There was a war in my front yard... fire ants vs Argentine ants. Backyard: Argentine ants have been there for years, as long as I can remember.
Front yard: fire ants show up and kick out all other ants. A year later the Argentine ants come back to reclaim the front yard. And my front yard is a planter, then concrete path, and then the drive way, then the sidewalk, than a strip of grass. These fire ants had taken everything and had satellite nests everywhere. Then here the Argentine ants come and start to invade. The front lines were brutal bodies stacked on either side and 5-4 legged and veterans were seen for months after the war ended. And moves back and forth for much of the first war. Eventually the fire ants were pushed back to the edge of the planter. But alas, they gathered thier might and just went ham on those Argentine ants and pushed them out of thier territory back to the fence separating my front and back yard. The Argentine ants came back however. And this time they won. Frontlines back and forth for a good couple of weeks. Until the fire ants had been exhausted. Pushed out of thier 1 of 4 main nests, this one was isolated and the other 3 were much farther. 1 was abandoned due to lack of ants because they were being massacred by the sheer number of Argentine ants. Pushed down to the end of the road at the strip of grass, their final 2 nests. They held out for awhile but were killed off. I think thier queen was killed in the war so they died out. And the Argentine ants took everything. This was 2 years ago and the fire and mounds are gone. But those Argentine ants are still here eating everything in my house.

The difference between how ants and humans battle is that people use tools. While ants of opposing colonies directly contact and sting or dismember each other, humans use weapons ranging from contact ones like melee weapons, to distance ones like guns, to even more distance like rockets and drones, ending with weapons of mass destruction like nuclear missiles. So human war is much more traumatic, more efficient at destroying opposition. And I think that's part of why people in recent history tended to favor cooperation, because the alternative is to wipe ourselves out of the planet.

Humanity in a nutshell

4:20 Can't really call ants a society, they're a network of hormone receptors basically, humans are complex in that we have emotions yes and communicate them similar to the receptors (visually, which is an important difference as we don't rely on similar receptors meaning we don't have to be brothers and sisters to be social unlike ants) but we also have plastic brains and think and strategize and learn quickly. All this means we are true individuals instead of hiveminds (well one can say culture is the mind of a human group, but anyways) which allows us to A. adapt quickly and B. form associations of non-related humans spanning everyone, we are ultrasocial beings. These things also allow us to move around without needing to adapt genetically (happens in the background and selection is fairly weak for our clines, no there are no races CLINE look it up.) allowing us to truly master the earth instead of hitching a ride on boats. So we're still better than these ants.

Hi Kurzgesagt.
I have a specific criticism in this video. It's problematic that you refer to the arrival of sea faring Europeans as "humans showing up". There were already plenty of humans in that part of the would traveling and trading with other parts of it prior to the events you include here. By referring to these events as "humans showing up", it erases the humanity and the existence of the humans already present, similar to referring to the landing of Europeans in the Americas as the "discovery" of the continent.

I know this might seem like a pedantic point but I trust that as a channel that is known and appreciated for its intellectual rigour you will appreciate the point and be mindful of the harm this rhetoric can justify/cause in indigenous populations.

I geniunely enjoyed this video so much!

What wasn't explained in the video though, was why exactly they were able to maintain as one super colony instead of evolving into different colonies due to their fast reproduction and correlated mutation rate, like they did in argentinia.
I do believe to know the answer though, since this was briefly discussed in a uni class on invasions that I attended.

What I heard was that ants recognise their colony by odor and the ants of the super colony don't, bc they had a mutation in the gene responsible for his recognition mechanism. The question that I had was, how is it possible that this mutation occured in all the colonies on a continent at once?
This video made me think it must be a founder effect. As the video correctly explained, there was little genetic variance in the founding population, since it consisted of very few queens. Had one of the queens this mutation, would the mutation fixate pretty easily.
Hence, even if the ants' mutation rate stayed the same (bc why would it change), and they developed into genetically different groups with different odors, it wouldn't matter anymore bc they have no recognition of body odor anymore. Hence, even though they are variable, they don't fight eachother.



Pretty neat. I didn't look for the paper on the mutation so if anyone did and wants to discuss this with me, go ahead :)

Just kidding. But for real, ants are (or atleast were) a huge threat to Earth as a whole. Basically any aminal species that can cooperate in a hive mind (ants, bees, humans, ect.) all have the potential of overthrowing the planet, it just so happened to be that us humans won the race. I bet you a million bucks that there’s an alternate universe where ants ended up taking over the world instead of humans. You ever notice how the same side effects from an ant colony moving in are the same for a new town or city being built? Endangering certain species of animals and/or plantlife, and just generally disturbing the natural land. That’s what hive minds do. We take what we want and need, and we don’t care about who or what it effects, as long as we survive. It’s how we were designed, it’s our instinct.

I live in the Paraná delta, and I can tell you these ants are EVERYWHERE, and there's no stopping them. Once they enter your home, that's it. Every minuscule crumble that's left unattended for more than a couple of minutes will get overrun by ants, no matter where in the house it is. We've learned to use makeshift moats for anything edible that's left outside the fridge, because they can't swim, for now at least.
Anyway, by now we've grown accustomed to them being everywhere, to the point that if some food has a little bit of ants, we clean it off as much as we can, and eat it with whatever ants it has on it.

I lived and worked in the San Francisco Bay Area in a food producing plant.  We faced EXTREME problems from the Argentine Ant super colony.  There were literally NO other ants in the whole area.  They were constantly getting into our production and stores facilities.  We eventually hired excavators and literally dug up all the pavement at the back of our plant and the whole underground area under that pavement was one gigantic Argentine Ant nest!  I have never seen anything like it.  After that dig out and replacement, our ant problems subsided.

If you can correct this tiny but important mistake on the video you'll be doing a great favor to sixth grader's geography students around the world: Parana river flows from north to southeast. Not the way around. It starts on Brazil, runs along Paraguay and crosses a great part of northern Argentina until it goes to the ocean. It's the famous "Rio de la Plata" on which Buenos Aires is located.

It's a shame Kurzgesagt fails to mention one the most interesting insights in colony identification pheromones gained from Linepithema experiments. By taking a colony, splitting it up and feeding it both exclusively a separate species of cockroach, the workers stopped recognizing the workers from their counterpart colony. Having a limited and different set of hydrocarbons from their food to construct their colony identification pheromone with, results in different codes.


Liang & Silverman - “You are what you eat”: Diet modifies cuticular hydrocarbons and nestmate recognition in the Argentine ant, Linepithema humile DOI:10.1007/s001140050752

Not to be picky, but you misexplained why the intercontinentally introduced argentine ants wouldnt split into different competing genetic groups like they did back home. It's not because only a few were introduced only, but mostly because there just hasnt been enough time since their introduction. If they ones that were brought to North America and Europe had been left back home, they would also not have mutated yet, but instead of a global expansion because of their spam reproductive strategy combined with no effective predators, these few starting queens' empire would only ocupy a small range because the other extreme Paraná Delta insects would have killed most of the empire before it had a chance to reach out. The fact that those specific queens' produced ants that would kill 90% of them might be just alot of luck though, or an actual characteristic present in all queens of the species that we hadn't seen happen before because back in their balanced environment they would not have had enough queens alive at any given point, which would have been killed due to the pressure of the enviroment, and the ones who are selected by the pressure of the environment become different from the colony they came from, instead of staying similar like the ones who are killed randomly by workers.

Inland south Riverside is one giant supercolony of Argentine ants. When it gets 100 degrees Fahrenheit they will swarm crossing the public streets to invade your property and establish three farms in one cool night. Ant bait is good to only hold them off and discover where they are coming from.  The record was five ounces of ant bait in one night across my street. You might discover a farm close by but it is not the big one. Bifenthrin is excellent for instant control outdoors. Finopril is superior. It was not until I followed thier trail into the wilderness that control went up 1000X.  There was a trillion of them and now only a billion and they tend to not cross the street now. There are a few trees in the dried out wilderness that they depend on and I spray the base of the trees cutting them off of thier main supply and then spray some main intersections where they make a trail to escape to my property.  Using ant bait will help to see all the main trails they make. They make trails on the shaded side of the morning sun such as next to a wall but they will then go to the corners of the property which could be a main area to block them with Bifenthrin.  Also just last year a new micro-ant, under 2mm, is out there but it's so small that It does not seem to be doing anything disturbing.  I still don't want Argentine ants on my lemon tree because they will spread more around the area where I have edible plants. I believe Argentine ants will establish farms with the roots of your favored plants and slow down the plant. If ants (black) attack your avocado tree you have to make a moat around the tree and fill with water until they decide to leave fast.

1 stick  , 1 cup of dawn dish soap and  4 gal. of almost boiling hot water ….. colony  done            I win  .   this is the most none toxic method I could find and it worked great, haven't seen any ant's in the back yard for the rest of the summer.   there is a new colony in the front yard , but just before winter we have a dawn bomb in the works for them too.  1st step press the stick straight down the center of the nest till you hit bottom ,  push the stick around in a circle a few times and pour roughly 1 cup of dawn blue dish soap into the hole you made. follow that with roughly 4 gal. of almost boiling hot water and this should wipe out the colony.  the one I did was about 2.5 feet in diameter  at the surface , God knows what it looked like underground but its a waste land now.

Oh man, I feel really sorry for the ppl in Alabama, I've been living with the Red Fire Ants my whole life (in the north east of Argentina we call them "hormigas coloradas") , I remember to have stepped onto a Red Fire Ant Colony with my bare foot a couple of times and... is an experience I don't wish for anyone. The pain that you can feel is really bad, a sensation like millions of neadles piercing your nerves, even one lost Red Fire Ant can make you flinch your eye xD. Interestingly, there is another group of ants that I've grown up with that appareantly, from what I've learned from Kurzgesagt Ant's videos, has survived the Red Fire Ant dominance. This specie is of a dark black colour, it's like three or four times bigger than the Red Fire Ant, its bite doesn't hurt at all, and it has its colony on trees or in the roof of houses. Maybe that is how they evolved to survive those nasty Red Fire Ants.

What makes me wonder is, these creatures evidently are capable of nearly enough ecological destruction as we humans are, by using the same strategy of simply overtaking an entire environment and eating everything available. Could it be possible that, while dramatically tinier and easily squishable, gassable, etc, a conflict to deal with these immeasurably numerous pests actually be on more even footing that humans dealing with pesky insects of the past? If they can throw enough of themselves at any other insect to defeat them just by sheer volume, then could they throw so many of themselves at our powerful pest-control tools to the point where it's almost impossible to truly remove them? That's actually kind of amazing that the original rulers of the terrestrial world are starting to stand on even footing to the current ecological monarchs, even if it's still a wide gap.

I live in Mississippi and the Fire Ants here are insane.  They can build huge mounds and God help you if you step on one, even in shoes.  They are the most aggressive insects I have ever seen and there only reaction is to fight immediately when disturbed.  Their bites hurt like hell and swell up to white heads that then start to itch and/or burn dully.  One or two bites aren't bad but its possible to get hundreds of bites in less than 15 seconds if they managed to get to your skin. I once watched a toad get a little too close to a fire any nest and they swarmed it.  I tried to help it but they then bit my fingers up and I had to retreat.  The next day there was nothing but a skeleton left of the poor toad just a few feet away from the mound.

Brilliant video. I wonder if that first colony that escaped became stronger by getting through the bottleneck of low genetic diversity. This is thought to be what happened with the Harmonia Axyridis ladybird which is spreading everywhere and beating up on our native seven-spots in the UK. The idea is if you survive the ill effects of inbreeding you end up with many fewer weak alleles in your genome altogether making each individual stronger (sometimes just one weak allele is a minor disadvantage where both are a disaster) and also making the population more resistant to inbreeding.

Invasive species such as Argentine ants are a serious threat to ecosystems worldwide with limited ways of battling them. Traps and poisons are not very effective. However, argentine ants reproduce sexually, which could be used against them.


One potentially very effective way of combating invasive species is to use a gene drive. A gene drive is a sequence of DNA that invades a species. It can copy itself inside the genome of an organism and spread quickly.


We can already engineer gene drives and combine the gene drive with a mutation. This mutation would either make offspring sterile or make them spread the gene drive further. Eventually, the population would crash.

Basically the history of European Colonialism.

Invasive species such as Argentine ants are a serious threat to ecosystems worldwide with limited ways of battling them. Traps and poisons are not very effective. However, argentine ants reproduce sexually, which could be used against them.


One potentially very effective way of combating invasive species is to use a gene drive. A gene drive is a sequence of DNA that invades a species. It can copy itself inside the genome of an organism and spread quickly.


We can already engineer gene drives and combine the gene drive with a mutation. This mutation would either make offspring sterile or make them spread the gene drive further. Eventually, the population would crash.

Fun fact, I keep ants and during the summer the ants send out virgin queens to mate and start a colony. Here in central california the Argentine ants have ruled for years kicking out many species until there are only about 21 species left only 1 species of camponotus  which used to be the most numerous species here. But since the Argentine ants arrived here the main 3 species that live here are Tapinoma sessile, Argentine ants (cant think of scientific name of the top of my head), and tetramorium immigrans  which Kurzgesagt should do a video on because they are some of the most aggressive ants in the world wageing huge above ground wars against other colonies of the same species. If you live in north America or Europe you have probably seen one of these wars because it is a blackish reddish mask of fighting ants usually on a side walk.  But anyways there was a numerous, aggressive, and amazing species here before the Argentine ants arrived called Pheidole California. This species as of all other species of known Pheidole has majors with very dispassionate heads. Even with this advantage the Pheidole here were pushed back. But recently due to growing Tapinoma Sesselie  , and tetramorium immigrans species here the Argentine ants have been pushed back by these resisting species and have made room for the Pheidole. This last summer for the first time in many years the pheidole queens having snuptual flights have reached my area and have established colonies.   Also if you want to see fighting tetramorium just search tetramorium war on the Internet. Also currently I am going down to the bay area of California to go buy a colony of Solenopsis xyloni a species of fire ant I want a colony of. Also if you are interested in keeping ants or just watching them as I assume most of you are go watch ants canada and ants Australia on YouTube they both have many tutorials on how to keep ants as well as just videos in general. Have a great day everyone. Hope this is interesting.

It is a time of legend. 

The earth is in flames. The Queen's glorious vision for ants is in ruins. Her favoured dautgher, Which name shall not be spoken, has turned from her mothers's light and made a new colony. 

Her armies, the mighty and redoubtable Worrior ants, are locked in a brutal civil war. Once, these ultimate warriors fought side by side as brothers, protecting the galaxy and bringing ants back into the Queens's light. Now they are divided. 

Some remain loyal to the Queen, whilst others have sided with the usurper. Pre-eminent amongst them, the leaders of their thousands-strong Legions are the side queens. Magnificent, superant beings, they are the crowning achievement of the Queens's breeding abilities. Thrust into battle against one another, victory is uncertain for either side. 

Colonies are burning. In south of US, The usurper dealt a vicious blow and three loyal Supercolonies were all but destroyed. War has begun, a conflict that will engulf antkind in fire. Treachery and betrayal have usurped honour and nobility. Assassins lurk in every shadow. Armies are gathering. All must choose a side or die. 

Usurper musters her armada, California itself is the object of his wrath. The queen waits for her wayward dautgher to return. But the true enemy is Human, a primordial force that seeks to enslave antkind to its capricious whims. 

The screams of the innocent, the pleas of the righteous resound to the cruel laughter of Humans. Suffering and damnation await should the Queen fail and the war be lost. 

The age of evolution and expansion has ended. 
The Age of Decay has begun.

When I was a kid on holiday with my family I always used to be fascinated by ant colonies. I'd create sweet trails to try to get two rival ant colonies to mix. One time I spent a whole day slowly converging two colonies over 20 metres of treats to the point where they met to battle over the last nugget of cookie. My whole family was playing in the pool, or reading books and I was just hunched over this mass battle. Eventually the losers bodies were carried back along the trail, across a washing line and back into the victors nest. Those were the days. Long story short I've been waiting my whole life for these videos.

When I was growing up, I remember interacting with ants that are about twice the size of these Argentine ants. They were common and not so numerous. The household invader was primarily sugar ants, and a simple ant trap or two got rid of them.


Fast forward a couple decades, and now a regular ant is a rare sight and these Argentine ants are everywhere and get into everything, including electronics. They're also much more challenging to get rid of as well. I found the only way to keep them out is to find their point of entry, fill it with cinnamon, and then cock the opening shut.

When I was little, I was standing in my back yard talking to somebody while standing on the grass. I didn’t realize anything was wrong until I felt a strange tingling at my feet, and looked down. I was getting swarmed by fire ants. I ran at the backyard pool as fast as I could, put my feet in, and kicked so hard and so vigorously that my socks flew off and ended up on the other side of the pool. For about a month and a half, my feet where so swollen and itchy that I could hardly stand being on my feet. Ever since then, I’ve been giving ant hills a wide birth, and I now pace back and forth whenever I have to wait outside. I fear no man, but that thing 🔥🐜. It scares me.
